If anyone is wondering, aluminium is, according to all modern authorities, technically correct. Where the debate comes in is because it was originally named aluminum in keeping with the Latin tradition (arum, ferrum, etc), but was later changed to be more in keeping with the tradition of the time (calcium, cesium, etc). Many argued though that they had no right to do this, since it's always been standard practice that whoever discovers a thing gets to name it and anyone who doesn't like the name can suck it because it's not their discovery to name.

Hence many argue that while aluminum is considered an acceptable variant, it should be the official pronunciation on the grounds that someone can't just rename someone else's discovery just because they think they have a better name in mind.

But that's neither here nor there and while I have my own opinion on the matter I'm sure even the people that read this post don't care to know it, so hopefully someone finds this trivia useful or interesting.

On the second experiment with the two towers, top and bottom.

The top tower collapses before the bottom one because it is growing against gravity. This is why it falls over, and the single tower does not. The tower's base becomes weakened by the contents moving down through the hole.

The bottom one is growing with the weight of gravity, causing it to grow at a faster rate than the top half. Just like the top half, the base of the tower's contents are moving in the opposite direction, and although occurring at a slower rate, the tower's mass will exceed it's structural integrity and eventually break off with the weight of gravity.
